column1: In a village on the slopes of Mount Kenya in East Africa
column2: a little girl worked in the fields with her mother. Her name was Wangari. Wangari loved being outside. In her family's food garden
column3: she broke up the soil with her machete. She pressed tiny seeds into the warm earth. Her favorite time of day was just after sunset. When it got too dark to see the plants
column4: Wangari knew it was time to go home. She would follow the narrow paths through the fields
column5: crossing rivers as she went. Wangari was a clever child and couldn't wait to go to school. But her mother and father wanted her to stay and help them at home. When she was seven years old
column6: her big brother persuaded her parents to let her go to school.She liked to learn! Wangari learned more and more with every book she read. She did so well at school that she was invited to study in the United States of America. Wangari was excited! She wanted to know more about the world.At the American university Wangari learned many new things. She studied plants and how they grow.
